You can wrap any renderable in padding which will extend padding to the full width.

```python
from rich.padding import Padding
console.print(Padding(ui_element))
```

> console.move_home console.clear_eos functions

Rich may or may not grow such things in the future. Possible as a separate package. Currently the line of separation is that Rich is for rendering only and not interactive. I broke that rule with the Progress display, so we'll see.

> -Column background color

You can set a style when you print something, which effectively does this. Try the following:

```python
from rich.columns import Columns
from rich.console import Console

console = Console()

from rich.table import Table

table = Table("foo", "bar", style="on blue")
table.add_row("1", "2")

console.print(Columns([table]*5, expand=True), style="on green")
```

Or you can wrap it in `Padding(columns, style="on magenta")`, which has a similar effect.

> Column justify for elements left,right,center,justify

I had thought the Align class does this, but its not working as intended. I should have a fix for this in the next version. Essentially you can wrap each column renderable in `Align.center(renderable)`. I'm not certain about making it a per-Columns attribute, but I'll think about it.

> -Mention progress.get_renderable() out in main documentation.

It's `get_renderables` which is recommended for this, and it's mentioned [here](https://rich.readthedocs.io/en/latest/progress.html#customizing). It doesn't go in to detail. Documentation PRs are welcome if you want to expand.

If you have any follow up questions, could you please open an issue per question. Makes it easier to track.

Not sure I fully grasped what you are trying to display with Columns, so perhaps add a screenshot?
You may want to try v3.2.0. I've added a `align` parameter to Columns constructor.

Sorry it took me so long to get back to you! Thank you for the help! It looks like wrapping the column in padding did the job exactly as needed! It leaves the tables pushed against each other to the left while clearing the space to the right with the background color needed. 

For what I meant by aligning columns, if you look at what the example code you put up does.
Align left would be to put your hand to the right side of the screen and push all of the boxes to the left so they are against each other and the left side of the screen.
Align right would be put your hand on the left side and push all of the boxes to the right of the screen.
Align center would be put a hand on either side and push them all together.

So it looks like everything was covered here and you've got the alignment going on already in columns, thank you again for the help and update!

If I understand you correctly, then this would do it:

```python
print(Align.left(columns))
print(Align.right(columns))
print(Align.center(columns))
```

You would need `expand=False` on the Column.
